title: Beware the Rocks!
review:

It's a 3in1 set and the alternate builds are called boathouse and seafood restaurant.  Included are two small reflective stickers and a light brick. Summary

I really like this set - I had been waiting for it's release and kind of forgot about it until I saw it high up on the shelf while checking out.

It was easy to build, didn't explode while being built, but still looks really cool and felt like I built something significant. The working light on top is fun to goof with. The seagulls and fish and minifig and life preserver ring and light brick are all nice. Not a ton of detail inside but the small stove and mug are a good start for adding your own touch.


Yet another great Creator set! And unlike too many other sets lately, I can't complain about the price at all. It's decent all around. I might have to get 1 for each build :)

author: dougts
title: Love It
review:
I'm a huge lighthouse buff, so I obviously had my eye on this set for awhile. The price point is pretty reasonable at $40 US, clocking in $10 higher than the recent log cabin, but there's a bit more here as well, so it feels about right.  The build was pretty straightforward and typical of a creator set.  Not much other than straight stud on top building, with the only real interesting bit being the crank gear that turns the reflector inside the top of the lighthouse.  the little boat is well designed - especially the motor, which tilts and has a spinning prop.  Great work on such a small item.  Finished product looks great as a display piece, right down to the seagulls.

Pros

  • Minifigure (seems we are to get 1 in all the creator "house" style sets going forward, as I see the upcoming hillside house is to have 1 as well)
  • Working Light with rotating reflector
  • Unique lattice round top door and lattice windows
  • neat little power boat

Cons

  • would have liked a true baseplate - maybe a 16x32 blue
  • interior of tower is not hollow
  • some minor mismatched colors (the two different grays in the walls, the yellow technic pieces). The former is likely due to the alternate builds, while the latter is probably piece availability
  • Feels like a piece is missing from the top, both to cover the protruding grey axle, and "finish" the lighthouse. a black  round "Final brick" would probably look nice.
All in all, I'm very pleased with the build, and like most Creator sets the value is good (at least for LEGO).  I'd love to see a much larger scale lighthouse in the future with a full interior spiral staircase, keeper's quarters, etc.  Until then, this will do nicely as a display piece in my office, which coincidentally has a lighthouse themed decor.

author: oscholes
title: Awesome set for a rainy night
review: I bought this on a bit of a whim recently, when I was looking for something to do on a rainy night. I absolutely love the creator series, and this is one of my favorites so far. The design is really good, and the build is moderately challenging - there are some slightly complicated elements, but overall it is quite straightforward. It's not the most "playable" set ever, but it does have some neat features, including the rotating light, and a few internal details like a ladder leading up to the light and a stove for the lighthouse keeper. I don't know if the minifigure is unique, but he's certainly unusual, and a nice addition to my collection. As with all the 3-in-1 sets, there are instructions for two other models, both of which provide a nice challenge, and a reasonable level of playability. Younger builders may struggle with all three designs, but older builders will absolutely find it a pleasant way to spend an evening. Bonus points for the light brick, which is a nice, relatively uncommon piece.

author: DrOrrery
title: Gem of a set
review:
When you take away the movie licenses, board games, collectible mini-figs and the like, Lego is really just about one thing:  Recreating a world in miniature, brick by brick.  That's what I love about Lego, and this set really epitomises that idea.  It is a perfect little creation that is fun to make and looks wonderful.

The build

The build here is fairly straight forward, it's a smallish model that all goes together reasonably easily.  It can be put together at a fairly leisurely place in about half an hour.  The other two builds are even more simple.  There's very little here that even a very young builder would have trouble with.  The two gear wheels that turn the lighthouse mirror by use of a crank are quite a nice little touch, a good introduction to how gears work for young children.

The completed model

This is a particularly good looking model.  The red and white lighthouse look itself is very iconic, but the details are what makes it.  The hand railings made out of rails, skeleton feet and taps at the ends come together perfectly, the little dock with its life preserver looks great, the barbeque grill, the seagulls, the way the side of the lighthouse opens up to show a small ladder and an oven inside.  The amount of detail they've put into this model is what really makes it fun.  And the previously mentioned handle and crank together with the light brick to make the lighthouse light up are very cool.  The smallest of the alternative models, the restaurant, has some very nice details as well.

Playability

Once you've built a lighthouse, there's a limited number of things you can do with it.  You're generally not, for instance, going to use it in a grand space battle (unless you've recently been watching that episode of The Goodies).  There are definitely things to do here, but the playability of this set, and the creator sets in general, seems to me to be more about building things with Lego rather than playing with the completed set.  With this model there are a lot of small, repeated pieces, a lot of different colours, and three sets of instructions for a start.  This is a set that is going to be taken apart and put back together a lot, and I think it's got a lot of possibility there.

Summary

This is a great set, and I think on of my favourites for the year.  It's small enough to be easy to build but big enough to be interesting.  If you like building as much as swooshing, put this one on the top of your list.

author: Mr__Minifigure
title: Excellent Creator set...
review:
I was very excited to get this set, and I was not disappointed! It's a lot of fun to build and play with after.


The Build:

I chose the lighthouse to build. I found it rewardingly challenging for a 500-piece set. It is a nice experience in the sense that it stays firmly together for the build instead of falling apart, but it has enough pieces & nuances to make you appreciate the build more. The fact that it has three things to build out of the same pieces, each arguably the same coolness. 

The Set:

Once built, it is very cool in appearance, and would make a great set for a brickfilm or LEGO layout. However, it is difficult to "play with" in the traditional sense, because, as the previous reviewer said, it's a lighthouse. For a lighthouse, it's as playable as it can get (and I mean that nicely). Compared to a helicopter, though, it is lacking. But it's a building, so whaddya expect? Compared against other buildings, it is quite fun, especially with the rotating light. 

The Summary:

I like it more than most buildings that I have. It's fun to build, useful as a prop in films or as a building on a layout, and fun to play with. It's also a steal for $40 with the number of unusual pieces and cool design.

author: DirtSquirt
title: Really Fun Set
review: I absolutely love the Creator series.  This is a great set.  All of the builds are really fun and the kids love to play with them.  There were some disappointments though. You have to put reflective stickers on 2 bricks for the lighthouse build but the stickers are not needed for the other two builds.  The bricks with the stickers on them need to be used and there is no where to hide them so they are out in the open and look out of place.  It would have been nice if an extra of each of those bricks was supplied.  Also, the boathouse and the seafood restaurant both have open doorways.  It would have been nice if they had supplied a door that would fit in that door frame as well.  Had those three items been included with the set, I would have rated it a 5.

author: Nesquik
title: Light-hearted fun
review:
One of the key features that makes a Creator product unique (in the LEGO universe, at least) is that you can build three different models in the same set. Of course, this doesn't always mean that two alternate builds are as impressive as the showcase variant, but combine this playability with the fact that Creator sets are generally constructed almost entirely from legacy LEGO components, and you have products that encourage more traditional values from this company.

The 5770 Lighthouse Island demonstrates why, besides the introduction of new themes of specialised components, the simplicity of the Creator products is only countered by their amazingly clever designs. The solutions are dealt with in creative ways, and not simply moulded into a single element.

This particular offering stands out because all three of the models (the Lighthouse, the Lifeboat Station and Seaside Cafe/Restaurant) are equally brilliant in their own way, and as with other Creator sets, are designed to appeal to different difficulty levels. For the younger audience, this means that they may build the Lifeboat Station one day, and then feel confident enough to move up to the Lighthouse in the next.

I have to focus on the Lighthouse first as it really is a thing of beauty. It took a good couple of hours (taking my time) to work through, but the end result typifies why LEGO is the ultimate construction toy. Simple things such as the ladder inside a constructed from plates and single-stud elements. The seagulls, which you would expect to arrive in a single mould, are brilliantly made again from little more than a handful of bricks and clever ideas. At the top of the Lighthouse, the railings are even held in place by skeleton legs, and yet blend in brilliantly with the rest of the design.

Some nice features extend the playability and cosiness of this product, such as the obvious Light Brick at the peak of the building. I have to confess that this won't blaze your room in a sheen of dazzling light, but the important thing is that it 'works', and can be functioned further with the rotating mirror section (worked through a crank on the size). Arguably the best concealed feature is that the side of the Lighthouse actually opens up to reveal what's inside. The man has a nice little stove (with chimney), a mug, the staircase and a beautiful window lattice. Even the front door is very unusual and fits perfectly into this set.

Although the Lighthouse would make a perfect addition to any child's harbour/city, it also makes for a perfect display piece. I'm not one to normally do this with LEGO because (A) it gets dusty, and (B) you run out of space. I made an exception with this product though as it reminds me of the many holidays and trips I've had to Devon, which itself is a lovely place.

The other builds in this set are simply nice additions, but I can't imagine that anyone would actually want to keep those designs built rather than the Lighthouse. The Lifeboat station makes a good functional toy for younger builders, and the cafe/restaurant adds a bit more challenge.

5770 really is the perfect Creator product at the moment, and importantly for most LEGO fans, is minifigure scale. Although I'm still unconvinced at how effective these 'Light Bricks' really are, they can add a touch of humour to sets such as the Lighthouse Island. All-in-all, this is LEGO at its best.

author: av8r1973
title: Outstanding design - clever build, full of detail
review:
I typically build the City sets with my daughters and save Creator sets for my wife.  She loves the houses.  This was no exception - she wanted the lighthouse.  The difference is that my 6yo daughter built it while my wife was cooking dinner.

I watched her and saw the creativity that was infused by TLG throughout the set.  The lightbrick idea was a bit corny to me until I saw how it worked.  Ingenious.  Very similar to working lights on emergency vehicles.

Unlike most other creator houses (except the log cabin), the building opens up and allows for play inside.  This is now important because TLG thought to include a minifig!  Thank you!

Other nice touches are the small boat necessary to reach the island and the gulls with fish.  Nicely done!  We won't be disassembling this one, but we need to get another couple for the B and C models - they both look great, too!

This one's a must-have for folks with any type of ocean scene or coast line in their City collection.  It blends in naturally.

author: Outer_Rim_Emperor
title: More impressive once built!
review: When I first saw this set I was pretty impressed with the overall design and the fact that the lighthouse actually lights up! I got this set for my last birthday and loved it even more so once I built the set. The lighthouse is a fairly decent size and works very well compared to minifig scale. I'm afraid the interior of the house is lacking somewhat but it was nice of LEGO to include a minifigure and boat for him to travel away in.

author: tatuvlakia
title: The Quintessential Lego set
review:
This is just what defines a great Lego set.

A very nice, detailed Lighthouse with two other very good alternative builds, although you will want to build the Lighthouse last because you will want to keep it built.

The Lighthouse could easily integrate with Town/City sets of ports and boats/ships.

It is an enormous plus for Creator sets to start including minifigs. I think that it adds a lot of value and it helps them integrate with the rest of sets better.

The light brick is a nice touch, and avoids gimmick-status by being central to the concept of a lighthouse, and the rotating mirror just completes this.

Watch out though because if you store your sets for prolonged periods, the battery in the light brick could corrode and ruin it. Removing it is not fast and easy, although simple enough if you unscrew and open the brick.

This set would benefit from buying multiples by stacking them together and having a twice-taller lighthouse, and maybe a bigger island.

I love the inclusion of a little boat too, completing a superbly rounded-off set.

Oh and those sea gulls with fish too!
